Key Words: Angina pectoris, pericarditis, aortic dissection, differential diagnosis
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn the differential diagnosis of chest pain.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn the key life threatening causes of chest pain.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To become familiar with Bayes Theorem.
[LIST_ITEM] Radiates to neck, jaw, shoulder or arms (L > R)
[LIST_ITEM] EKG: Transient STE or ST depression
[LIST_ITEM] EKG: Typically PR depression and ST elevation
[LIST_ITEM] Precipitated by foods or supine position (night-time)
[LIST_ITEM] Brought on by fatty foods, not exertion
[LIST_ITEM] Not relieved by antacids or NTG
[LIST_ITEM] Sternal pain worsened by chest movement
[LIST_ITEM] Relieved by antiinflammatory agent or steroid injection
[LIST_ITEM] May be chest and/or back pain
[LIST_ITEM] Pulse deficits or aortic valve insufficiency
[LIST_ITEM] Deep steady pain located at site of pressure on musculoskeletal system
[LIST_ITEM] May have cough, dysphagia, or other sx from local compression
[H1] DIAGNOSTIC TESTS IN PATIENTS WITH CHEST PAIN.

|  TEST | TARGET DIAGNOSIS  | | --- | --- | |  EKG | • Myocardial ischemia  | |  CXR | • Pericarditis  | |  Upper GI series or endoscopy | • Aortic dissection or aneurysm  | |   | • GERD  | |   | • Ulcer  |
[H1] DIAGNOSTIC TESTS IN PATIENTS WITH CHEST PAIN.

|  TEST | TARGET DIAGNOSIS  | | --- | --- | |  Abdomen ultra sound | • Gall stones  | |  Chest CT or MRI | • Aortic disease  | |  Esophageal motility | • Pulmonary embolus  | |  VQ scan/CT Angio | • Esophageal spasm  | |  Stress test/CT Angio | • Pulmonary embolus  | |   | • Angina  |
[H1] DIAGNOSTIC TESTS IN PATIENTS WITH CHEST PAIN.
Pre test Probability → Test → Post test Probability
